original_data.question: A 22-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of irregular menstrual bleeding. Menses have occurred at 45- to 90-day intervals since menarche at the age of 15 years. Her last menstrual period was 5 weeks ago. The patient reports that she was too embarrassed to discuss this issue with anyone until now. Over the past two years, she was unable to become pregnant despite having unprotected sexual intercourse with her husband on a regular basis. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. She is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 85 kg (187 lb); BMI is 29.4 kg/m2. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows oily skin and severe facial acne. There is abnormal pigmented hair on the upper lip and around both nipples. The patient wishes to have children. In addition to recommending lifestyle modifications, which of the following is the most appropriate step in management?

options.A: In vitro fertilization with patient's egg

model_response:
The patient has PCOS. The ovaries are enlarged and have a smooth, thickened capsule. The cut surface shows a multitude of small cysts (later identified as follicles) arranged in a cluster around the periphery, with a central stellate scar. The patient is obese, with a BMI of 29.4 kg/m2. Obesity and hirsutism are common in PCOS. The patient has not menstruated for 5 weeks, and progesterone therapy will induce a withdrawal bleed. Clomiphene therapy is used to induce ovulation in patients who are anovulatory. Leuprolide therapy is used to suppress the abnormal hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis. In vitro fertilization with the patient's egg is not appropriate because she is hirsute and has not menstruated for 5 weeks.

Answer: OPTION B IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Individuals licensed to practice medicine.
Systematic, objective appraisal of the significance, effectiveness, and impact of activities or condition according to specified objectives and criteria.
Lacking perfect symmetry or evenness.

Abnormal uterine bleeding that is not related to MENSTRUATION, usually in females without regular MENSTRUAL CYCLE. The irregular and unpredictable bleeding usually comes from a dysfunctional ENDOMETRIUM.

The periodic shedding of the ENDOMETRIUM and associated menstrual bleeding in the MENSTRUAL CYCLE of humans and primates. Menstruation is due to the decline in circulating PROGESTERONE, and occurs at the late LUTEAL PHASE when LUTEOLYSIS of the CORPUS LUTEUM takes place.
A time period, or other type of interval, during which something may be achieved, obtained or observed.
The first MENSTRUAL CYCLE marked by the initiation of MENSTRUATION.
How long something has existed; elapsed time since birth.
A period of time that it takes for Earth to make a complete revolution around the sun, approximately 365 days; a specific one year period.

The periodic shedding of the ENDOMETRIUM and associated menstrual bleeding in the MENSTRUAL CYCLE of humans and primates. Menstruation is due to the decline in circulating PROGESTERONE, and occurs at the late LUTEAL PHASE when LUTEOLYSIS of the CORPUS LUTEUM takes place.

The periodic shedding of the ENDOMETRIUM and associated menstrual bleeding in the MENSTRUAL CYCLE of humans and primates. Menstruation is due to the decline in circulating PROGESTERONE, and occurs at the late LUTEAL PHASE when LUTEOLYSIS of the CORPUS LUTEUM takes place.
Any period of seven consecutive days.

An indication that the patient provides information about their vital signs, status, or subjective feelings. Some systems also consider information reported by the patient's family or guardian as patient-reported.
A difficulty, disorder, or condition needing resolution.
A period of time that it takes for Earth to make a complete revolution around the sun, approximately 365 days; a specific one year period.
Observed to be or have been pregnant.
Sexual intercourse without the use of precautions to prevent conception or the transmission of sexually transmitted diseases.
The sexual union of a male and a female, a term used for human only.
A male partner in marriage.
A record of a patient's background regarding health and disease events of blood relatives. A patient's family medical history may be important in diagnosing existing conditions.
A state of ill health, bodily malfunction, or discomfort.
The mass or quantity of heaviness of an individual. It is expressed by units of pounds or kilograms.
Actions performed to measure temperature, pulse, respirations, and blood pressure
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
Intensely bad or unpleasant in degree, quality or extent.
The anterior portion of the head that includes the skin, muscles, and structures of the forehead, eyes, nose, mouth, cheeks, and jaw.
Deviating in any way from the state, position, structure, condition, behavior, or rule which is considered a norm.

A filament-like structure consisting of a shaft which projects to the surface of the SKIN from a root which is softer than the shaft and lodges in the cavity of a HAIR FOLLICLE. It is found on most surfaces of the body.
Lip, each instance of which is the fleshy margin of the mouth that bounds superiorly some oral orifice.
The conic organs which usually give outlet to milk from the mammary glands.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
A person 6 to 12 years of age. An individual 2 to 5 years old is CHILD, PRESCHOOL.
Typical way of life or manner of living characteristic of an individual or group. (From APA, Thesaurus of Psychological Index Terms, 8th ed)
The act of alteration or modification; changed or altered in form or character.
Performing or possessing executive duties; acting as a supervisor or manager.
